advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 ! <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (APR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Larry Greenfield and his <a href="http://www.tcp.com/%7Elgreenf/apfpage.htm" target="_blank">APF Imagination Machine page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A step toward the future" <br><br> Hmmmm.....</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, APRIL 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> It's an extraordinarily powerful machine which offers word-processing, spreadsheet, and a set of time and data-management tools in a single, highly porlable package.<br> At £199.95. the Z88 is supplied with 32K resident RAM. Extra 32K costs under £20, extra 128K under £50!<br> And heavy users Will be able to expand the RAM to an astonishing 3 Mbytes, using plug-in RAM cartridges.<br> For printing text or data, the Z88 connects direcly to most popular RS232 compatible printers, while for permanent storage the Z88 employs removable solid state EPROM cartridges - no tape to break, no delicate disc to damage.<br> Though the Z88 is a powerful, full facility, self-contained computer, it also acts as an extension of an office micro, connecting directly to allow exchange of text or data.<br> For every personal computer user, the Z88 offers a comprehensive specification in a package of unparalleled portability.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD. JUNE 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (NOV. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same offer and same sale prices as in December 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOG (1992)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one ! </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Ball angle, Ball Speed, Paddle Size
computer.description:
The Blaupunkt TV-Action pong console is one of the few video games system not to use a standard TV Video output. This way, the TV-Action is only compliant with a short range of TV, all designed and created by Blaupunkt : Jamaica, Riviera, Nevada and Columbia series. Some other companies, such as Grundig, had the same politic and created some system that were only compliant with their own brand?s TV sets.
It?s important to notice that, on this system, no external power supply is required, as it comes directly from the TV set on which the video game system is connected to... using the same cord as for game display (video).
Except for this connectivity weirdness, the TV-Action is nothing but a classic Pong system, providing 4 different games (Tennis, Pelota, Hockey and Squash), with the classical speed/size/angle options. It?s composed of two controllers : the main one is directly connected to the TV set and contains all the games options & hardware (GI chip), while the second controller, connected to the first one, is smaller and offer a slider used by the second player to move his paddle.
___________
Text, info & pictures by Fran?ois Houste.
computer.name: TV-Action
